trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Blob Storage and Visual Studio connected services | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Blob Storage and Visual Studio connected services | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to get started using Azure Blob Storage in a cloud service project in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: How to get started using Azure Blob Storage in a cloud service project in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to get started with Azure Blob Storage after you created or referenced an Azure Storage account by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog in a Visual Studio cloud services project.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to get started with Azure Blob Storage after you created or referenced an Azure Storage account by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog in a Visual Studio cloud services project.

trans-unit.source: We'll show you how to access and create blob containers, and how to perform common tasks like uploading, listing, and downloading blobs.
trans-unit.target: We'll show you how to access and create blob containers, and how to perform common tasks like uploading, listing, and downloading blobs.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C\# and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C\# and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob Storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob Storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: A single blob can be any size.
trans-unit.target: A single blob can be any size.

trans-unit.source: Blobs can be things like images, audio and video files, raw data, and document files.
trans-unit.target: Blobs can be things like images, audio and video files, raw data, and document files.

trans-unit.source: Just as files live in folders, storage blobs live in containers.
trans-unit.target: Just as files live in folders, storage blobs live in containers.

trans-unit.source: After you have created a storage, you create one or more containers in the storage.
trans-unit.target: After you have created a storage, you create one or more containers in the storage.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a storage called “Scrapbook,” you can create containers in the storage called “images” to store pictures and another called “audio” to store audio files.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a storage called “Scrapbook,” you can create containers in the storage called “images” to store pictures and another called “audio” to store audio files.

trans-unit.source: After you create the containers, you can upload individual blob files to them.
trans-unit.target: After you create the containers, you can upload individual blob files to them.

trans-unit.source: For more information on programmatically manipulating blobs, see <linkText>How to use blob storage from .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on programmatically manipulating blobs, see <linkText>How to use blob storage from .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For general information about Azure Storage,see <linkText>Storage documentation</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For general information about Azure Storage,see <linkText>Storage documentation</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For general information about Azure Cloud Services, see <linkText>Cloud Services documentation</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For general information about Azure Cloud Services, see <linkText>Cloud Services documentation</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more information about programming ASP.NET applications, see <linkText>ASP.NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about programming ASP.NET applications, see <linkText>ASP.NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To programmatically access blobs in cloud service projects, you need to add the following items, if they're not already present.
trans-unit.target: To programmatically access blobs in cloud service projects, you need to add the following items, if they're not already present.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C# file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C# file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudStorageAccount object that represents your storage account information.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudStorageAccount object that represents your storage account information.

trans-unit.source: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.
trans-unit.target: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudBlobClient object to reference an existing container in your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudBlobClient object to reference an existing container in your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudBlobContainer object to reference a specific blob container.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudBlobContainer object to reference a specific blob container.

trans-unit.source: Use all of the code shown in the previous procedure in front of the code shown in the following sections.
trans-unit.target: Use all of the code shown in the previous procedure in front of the code shown in the following sections.

trans-unit.source: Some APIs that perform calls out to Azure Storage in ASP.NET are asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: Some APIs that perform calls out to Azure Storage in ASP.NET are asynchronous.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Asynchronous programming with Async and Await</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Asynchronous programming with Async and Await</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: The code in the following example assumes that you are using async programming methods.
trans-unit.target: The code in the following example assumes that you are using async programming methods.

trans-unit.source: To create a container in your storage account, all you need to do is add a call to CreateIfNotExistsAsync as in the following code:
trans-unit.target: To create a container in your storage account, all you need to do is add a call to CreateIfNotExistsAsync as in the following code:

trans-unit.source: To make the files within the container available to everyone, you can set the container to be public by using the following code.
trans-unit.target: To make the files within the container available to everyone, you can set the container to be public by using the following code.

trans-unit.source: Anyone on the Internet can see blobs in a public container, but you can modify or delete them only if you have the appropriate access key.
trans-unit.target: Anyone on the Internet can see blobs in a public container, but you can modify or delete them only if you have the appropriate access key.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage supports block blobs and page blobs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage supports block blobs and page blobs.

trans-unit.source: In the majority of cases, block blob is the recommended type to use.
trans-unit.target: In the majority of cases, block blob is the recommended type to use.

trans-unit.source: To upload a file to a block blob, get a container reference and use it to get a block blob reference.
trans-unit.target: To upload a file to a block blob, get a container reference and use it to get a block blob reference.

trans-unit.source: Once you have a blob reference, you can upload any stream of data to it by calling the UploadFromStream method.
trans-unit.target: Once you have a blob reference, you can upload any stream of data to it by calling the UploadFromStream method.

trans-unit.source: This operation creates the blob if it didn't previously exist, or overwrites it if it does exist.
trans-unit.target: This operation creates the blob if it didn't previously exist, or overwrites it if it does exist.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to upload a blob into a container and assumes that the container was already created.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to upload a blob into a container and assumes that the container was already created.

trans-unit.source: To list the blobs in a container, first get a container reference.
trans-unit.target: To list the blobs in a container, first get a container reference.

trans-unit.source: You can then use the container's ListBlobs method to retrieve the blobs and/or directories within it.
trans-unit.target: You can then use the container's ListBlobs method to retrieve the blobs and/or directories within it.

trans-unit.source: To access the rich set of properties and methods for a returned IListBlobItem, you must cast it to a CloudBlockBlob, CloudPageBlob, or CloudBlobDirectory object.
trans-unit.target: To access the rich set of properties and methods for a returned IListBlobItem, you must cast it to a CloudBlockBlob, CloudPageBlob, or CloudBlobDirectory object.

trans-unit.source: If the type is unknown, you can use a type check to determine which to cast it to.
trans-unit.target: If the type is unknown, you can use a type check to determine which to cast it to.

trans-unit.source: The following code demonstrates how to retrieve and output the URI of each item in the photos container:
trans-unit.target: The following code demonstrates how to retrieve and output the URI of each item in the photos container:

trans-unit.source: As shown in the previous code sample, the blob service has the concept of directories within containers, as well.
trans-unit.target: As shown in the previous code sample, the blob service has the concept of directories within containers, as well.

trans-unit.source: This is so that you can organize your blobs in a more folder-like structure.
trans-unit.target: This is so that you can organize your blobs in a more folder-like structure.

trans-unit.source: For example, consider the following set of block blobs in a container named photos:
trans-unit.target: For example, consider the following set of block blobs in a container named photos:

trans-unit.source: When you call ListBlobs on the container (as in the previous sample), the collection returned contains CloudBlobDirectory and CloudBlockBlob objects representing the directories and blobs contained at the top level.
trans-unit.target: When you call ListBlobs on the container (as in the previous sample), the collection returned contains CloudBlobDirectory and CloudBlockBlob objects representing the directories and blobs contained at the top level.

trans-unit.source: Here is the resulting output:
trans-unit.target: Here is the resulting output:

trans-unit.source: Optionally, you can set the UseFlatBlobListing parameter of of the ListBlobs method to true.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, you can set the UseFlatBlobListing parameter of of the ListBlobs method to true.

trans-unit.source: This results in every blob being returned as a CloudBlockBlob, regardless of directory.
trans-unit.target: This results in every blob being returned as a CloudBlockBlob, regardless of directory.

trans-unit.source: Here is the call to ListBlobs:
trans-unit.target: Here is the call to ListBlobs:

trans-unit.source: and here are the results:
trans-unit.target: and here are the results:

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CloudBlobContainer.ListBlobs</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CloudBlobContainer.ListBlobs</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To download blobs, first retrieve a blob reference and then call the DownloadToStream method.
trans-unit.target: To download blobs, first retrieve a blob reference and then call the DownloadToStream method.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the DownloadToStream method to transfer the blob contents to a stream object that you can then persist to a local file.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses the DownloadToStream method to transfer the blob contents to a stream object that you can then persist to a local file.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the DownloadToStream method to download the contents of a blob as a text string.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the DownloadToStream method to download the contents of a blob as a text string.

trans-unit.source: To delete a blob, first get a blob reference and then call the Delete method.
trans-unit.target: To delete a blob, first get a blob reference and then call the Delete method.

trans-unit.source: If you are listing a large number of blobs, or you want to control the number of results you return in one listing operation, you can list blobs in pages of results.
trans-unit.target: If you are listing a large number of blobs, or you want to control the number of results you return in one listing operation, you can list blobs in pages of results.

trans-unit.source: This example shows how to return results in pages asynchronously, so that execution is not blocked while waiting to return a large set of results.
trans-unit.target: This example shows how to return results in pages asynchronously, so that execution is not blocked while waiting to return a large set of results.

trans-unit.source: This example shows a flat blob listing, but you can also perform a hierarchical listing, by setting the useFlatBlobListing parameter of the ListBlobsSegmentedAsync method to false.
trans-unit.target: This example shows a flat blob listing, but you can also perform a hierarchical listing, by setting the useFlatBlobListing parameter of the ListBlobsSegmentedAsync method to false.

trans-unit.source: Because the sample method calls an asynchronous method, it must be prefaced with the async keyword, and it must return a Task object.
trans-unit.target: Because the sample method calls an asynchronous method, it must be prefaced with the async keyword, and it must return a Task object.

trans-unit.source: The await keyword specified for the ListBlobsSegmentedAsync method suspends execution of the sample method until the listing task completes.
trans-unit.target: The await keyword specified for the ListBlobsSegmentedAsync method suspends execution of the sample method until the listing task completes.
